system: You are a helpful assistant on Ò.
response: Ò, ò (o-grave) is a letter of the Latin script. It is used in Catalan, Emilian, Lombard, Papiamento, Occitan, Kashubian, Romagnol, Sardinian, Scottish Gaelic, Taos, Vietnamese, Haitian Creole, Louisiana Creole, Norwegian, Welsh and Italian. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%92)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ò.
You are a helpful assistant on Ò.
response: In Chinese pinyin, ò is the yángqù tone (阳去, falling tone) of "o". <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%92)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ò.
response: Ò is used to represent Emilian pronunciation: [ɔː], e.g. òs Emilian pronunciation: [ɔːs] "bone". <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%92)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ò.
response: In Italian, the grave accent is used over any vowel to indicate word-final stress: Niccolò (equivalent of Nicholas and the forename of Machiavelli). It can also be used on the nonfinal vowels o and e to indicate that the vowel is stressed and that it is open: còrso, "Corsican", vs. córso, "course"/"run", the past participle of "correre". Ò represents the open-mid back rounded vowel /ɔ/ and È represents the open-mid front unrounded vowel /ɛ/. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%92)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ò.
response: Ò is the 28th letter of the Kashubian alphabet and represents /wɛ/, like the pronunciation of ⟨we⟩ in "wet". <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%92)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ò.
response: It is used to represent vocalic phonemes /ɔ/ and /ɔː/ in every tonic occurrence to distinguish them from /o/ and /oː/ represented by O, e.g. fiòrd /ˈfjɔːrd/ (fjord) and sord /ˈsuːrd/ (deaf); còta /ˈkɔta/ (cooked) and sota /ˈsota/ (under/below). <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%92)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ò.
response: It is used to represent /ɔ/ by many (but not all) speakers to distinguish it from /o/, represented by o. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%92)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ò.
response: In Macedonian, о̀̀ is used to differentiate the word о̀̀д (English: walk) from the more common од (English: from). Both о̀̀ and о are pronounced as [o]. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%92)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ò.
response: Ò can be found in the Norwegian word òg which is an alternative spelling of også, meaning "also". This word is found in both Nynorsk and Bokmål. <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%92)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ò.
response: Ò is used to represent Romagnol pronunciation: [ɔ], e.g. piò Romagnol pronunciation: [pjɔ] "more". <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%92)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ò.
response: In the Vietnamese alphabet, ò is the huyền tone (falling tone) of "o". <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%92)

system: You are a helpful assistant on Ò.
response: In Welsh, ò is sometimes used, usually in words borrowed from another language, to mark vowels that are short when a long vowel would normally be expected, e.g., clòs (English: close [of the weather]). <LINK>(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%92)
